posts.name:
Adam P. Boyd
Adam P. Boyd
posts.content:
8 lessons I learned in a 73mm fintech company 

One fall, I got a call from a companyâ€™s COO out of New York.

Their sales team had missed the mark (again), even though they said they are doing everything they can (sound familiar?).

I dove in and from the outside, everything looked great.

But digging deeper, I found a mess.

Their situation is that of many companies Iâ€™ve consulted and trained in the past.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned working with them and many others like them:

1ï¸âƒ£ Big companies donâ€™t have all the answers.
2ï¸âƒ£ A sales problem is usually a sales leadership problem.
3ï¸âƒ£ The usual suspects: hiring the wrong people, not managing data well, running poor processes, not training and developing people appropriately.
4ï¸âƒ£ A lot of answers are simple ones.
5ï¸âƒ£ A lot of solutions start with holding people accountable.
6ï¸âƒ£ A lack of curiosity and a willingness to look at how the engine is running.
7ï¸âƒ£ Knowing where to look for core issues is a learned skill, but can be taught to smart, hungry, humble leaders.
8ï¸âƒ£ A refusal to accept â€œthis is how weâ€™ve always done thisâ€

If youâ€™re reading this and sales arenâ€™t where you want them to be.

Where do you need to inspect:

Your data?
Your people?
Your process?
Your systems?
Your training?
How does your customer buy?

Just start looking and challenging the status quo within your org.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

comments.commentText: not in a hateful way ... the wrong people doesn't mean they are wrong persons ... they just aren't a fit for the company ... but it is actually empathetic or at least compassionate to fire fast ... it allows people to not waste more of their time either as they are are a right fit somewhere ... accountability ... hire slow (the right people) ... fire fast (because it is not fair to your company OR fair to the "wrong person") ...
great word. and a beautiful way of saying it.
Love your point on accountability and clear expectations. That's where I find the issue when I lift up the hood Adam P. Boyd
Albert Ramos Jr. itâ€™s not complicated, is it?

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing accountability and challenging the status quo can truly transform a sales teams performance. Thank you for sharing!

Life throws challenges at us, and when things go wrong, it's natural to think, "Why is this happening to me?" 

But over the years, Iâ€™ve learned that asking a different question can change everything:
"What is this trying to teach me?"

This simple shift has completely transformed how I deal with setbacks. Instead of feeling stuck, I start looking for the lesson hidden in the struggle.

â— A missed opportunity? It taught me patience.
â— A failure? It pushed me to improve.
â— A tough conversation? It helped me grow emotionally.


 Remember - Every experience, no matter how difficult, carries a messageâ€”if weâ€™re willing to look for it.

So, next time youâ€™re faced with a challenge, try shifting your perspective. You might be surprised how much it helps.


Have you experienced the power of this shift? I'd love to hear your thoughts and stories in the comments!

comments.commentText: Neha, your perspective on embracing challenges as opportunities for growth is truly inspiring. The idea of reframing setbacks into learning moments resonates deeply with me. It's amazing how this shift can lead to personal development and resilience in our professional journeys. Thank you for sharing such valuable insights!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing challenges as lessons is a game changer. Thank you for inspiring us to shift our mindset! #GrowthMindset

posts.content:
An article from Vox caught my attention recentlyâ€”Microsoft's Copilot Vision is taking AI integration to a new level. This tool connects with web pages in real time, offering tailored assistance based on what users are doing. It's not just reactiveâ€”it's proactive, aiming to make our interactions with technology feel more intuitive and seamless.

What I find most interesting here is the potential to change how we think about productivity. Instead of seeing AI as a standalone tool, innovations like Copilot Vision weave it into our routines, anticipating needs and streamlining workflows in ways that feel effortless.

What do you think? Are we ready for AI to be this deeply integrated into our lives?

posts.commentAdded: Exciting developments! I believe integrating AI like Copilot Vision can truly enhance productivity. Looking forward to seeing its impact!

posts.name:
Jean Larkin
Jean Larkin
posts.content:
50% of U.S. employees are NOT thriving in their lives. 

Let that sink in. 

ğ—›ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—³ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—² ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—´ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´. And this isnâ€™t just a personal problemâ€”itâ€™s an organizational crisis.

When employees arenâ€™t thriving, hereâ€™s what happens:
 Productivity drops.
 Absenteeism spikes.
 Turnover skyrockets.

According to Gallupâ€™s latest research, weâ€™ve hit a record low in employee life evaluationsâ€”the worst since 2009. Even more alarming? The percentage of employees who believe their organizations care about their well-being is well below pre-pandemic levels.

This is not sustainable.

Employee wellbeing is no longer a â€œnice-to-have.â€ Itâ€™s the foundation for sustainable performance. Thriving employees are:

ï¸ Healthier (less absenteeism).
ï¸ More loyal (reduced turnover).
ï¸ More engaged (better performance).

Yet, many leaders have let wellbeing initiatives slide. They assume that a return to â€œbusiness as usualâ€ is what we need. That "getting back to work" will fix the cracks. It wonâ€™t.

So, what can we do as leaders?

At Octopy, weâ€™ve seen the power of intentional leadership in transforming workplaces and creating thriving cultures. Here are three actionable strategies we teach to leaders:

1ï¸âƒ£ Listen to understand, not to respond.

At Octopy, we believe that feedback loops arenâ€™t optionalâ€”theyâ€™re essential. Create systems where employees feel heard and their feedback drives meaningful change. Start small: regular one-on-ones or team retrospectives can do wonders.

2ï¸âƒ£ Cultivate authentic connections and increase trust.

Our workshops emphasize the importance of empowering authentic connections. Employees need to feel safe being themselves and sharing challenges without fear of repercussions. Trust isnâ€™t just a feeling; itâ€™s built through consistency over time.

3ï¸âƒ£ Simplify what matters, values-aligned focus helps.

Too often, leaders overcomplicate goals. At Octopy, we help organizations focus on what truly drives impact. When you clear the noise, employees can channel their energy into what matters mostâ€”both professionally and personally.

Thriving workplaces are built by leaders who prioritize wellbeing through intentional actions.

At Octopy, weâ€™ve seen firsthand how aligning leadership behaviors with employee needs drives better results, higher retention, and a more engaged workforce.

 How is your organization prioritizing employee wellbeing in 2025? Let me know in the comments.

comments.commentText: Always strive to listen to understand! The response is far less important than understanding. Creating feedback loops where employees feel genuinely heard can transform trust, engagement, and retention.

posts.commentAdded: This is a crucial issue! Intentional leadership can transform workplaces. Excited to see how organizations like Octopy champion employee wellbeing!
